headline.main: Plane Crash in Georgia Kills 23, Including Former Senator Tower

results.snippet: A commuter plane carrying 23 people, including former Senator John G. Tower of Texas, crashed and burned today a mile and a half short of the airport near this Georgia coast city, killing everyone on board.    The twin-engine turbo-prop Atlantic...

byline.original: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A commuter plane carrying 23 people, including former Senator John G. Tower of Texas, crashed and burned today a mile and a half short of the airport near this Georgia coast city, killing everyone on board. The twin-engine turbo-prop Atlantic Southeast Airlines plane flying from Atlanta went down in a thickly wooded area within view of motorists on Interstate 95 shortly before 3 P.M., the police said.

headline.main: Backgrounds of Astronauts On the 39th Shuttle Mission

results.snippet: Steven R. Nagel Mission Commander   Colonel Nagel, a 44-year-old Air Force pilot, made his first trip into space six years ago as a mission specialist. Later that same year, he piloted the West German space lab mission.

headline.main: Capt. Manley Lanier Carter, 43; Physician and Shuttle Astronaut

results.snippet: Capt. Manley Lanier Carter Jr. of the Navy, the astronaut who was killed yesterday when a commuter airliner crashed in Georgia, was a physician who spent 120 hours in orbit aboard the space shuttle Discovery on a secret military venture.    Captain...
results.lead_paragraph: Capt. Manley Lanier Carter Jr. of the Navy, the astronaut who was killed yesterday when a commuter airliner crashed in Georgia, was a physician who spent 120 hours in orbit aboard the space shuttle Discovery on a secret military venture. Captain Carter, 43 years old, played professional soccer with the Atlanta Chiefs before completing his medical studies at Emory University in 1973. Known as Sonny, Captain Carter was born in Macon, Ga., and became an astronaut six years ago. The mission specialist was assigned to the crew preparing for the maiden flight of the International Microgravity Laboratory.

headline.main: Astronauts Ready to Release Gamma Ray Satellite

results.snippet: The space shuttle astronauts have flexed their 50-foot mechanical arm, inspected gear for a spacewalk and checked the performance of the big satellite in the cargo bay -- all in preparation for the high point of their mission, the deployment of the...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle astronauts have flexed their 50-foot mechanical arm, inspected gear for a spacewalk and checked the performance of the big satellite in the cargo bay -- all in preparation for the high point of their mission, the deployment of the Gamma Ray Observatory on Sunday. The release of the 17-ton, $600 million observatory, the heaviest satellite to be carried by a shuttle, is scheduled to be completed by 2 P.M.

headline.main: Inquiry Begins Into Georgia Plane Crash

results.snippet: As investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board today began piecing together the causes of a commuter airliner crash that killed former Senator John G. Tower and 22 others, Elaine Gwin quietly grieved by the side of Touchstone...

byline.original: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: As investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board today began piecing together the causes of a commuter airliner crash that killed former Senator John G. Tower and 22 others, Elaine Gwin quietly grieved by the side of Touchstone Parkway.

headline.main: In Tennis, Child Prodigies Whet the Agents' Appetites

results.snippet: The next time an ambitious parent hangs a cute tennis mobile above a child's crib the way Andre Agassi's father once did, there could very well be an agent standing by to jiggle it with one hand and sign the prodigy to a business contract with the...
results.lead_paragraph: The next time an ambitious parent hangs a cute tennis mobile above a child's crib the way Andre Agassi's father once did, there could very well be an agent standing by to jiggle it with one hand and sign the prodigy to a business contract with the other. In the tennis industry there is a veritable race to rob the cradle.

headline.main: Spacewalking Astronaut Repairs Satellite With a Quick Push

results.snippet: Two astronauts took a spacewalk outside the shuttle Atlantis today to make an emergency repair of a major malfunction, freeing a jammed antenna and clearing the way for deploying an astronomy satellite that is to observe the mysteries of galaxies...

byline.original: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts took a spacewalk outside the shuttle Atlantis today to make an emergency repair of a major malfunction, freeing a jammed antenna and clearing the way for deploying an astronomy satellite that is to observe the mysteries of galaxies and black holes. About all it took was a space-age version of kicking the tires.

headline.main: How About A Shuttle Without Astronauts?

results.snippet: AS astronauts guided the space shuttle Atlantis to a smooth landing last week and then celebrated the 10th anniversary of the first shuttle flight, NASA was quietly wrestling with growing pressure to endow the winged spaceships with the ability to...
results.lead_paragraph: AS astronauts guided the space shuttle Atlantis to a smooth landing last week and then celebrated the 10th anniversary of the first shuttle flight, NASA was quietly wrestling with growing pressure to endow the winged spaceships with the ability to steer themselves back to earth, putting astronauts and their skills on the sideline. Automatic landings raise the thorny question of whether humans could be eliminated entirely from the craft's operation. In theory, the shuttle could carry some payloads into orbit without the aid of astronauts, reducing the repercussions from a Challenger-type disaster. The odds of catastrophic failure are seen as 1 in 78 missions.

headline.main: Review/Television; As Networks Go Rural, CBS Goes a Bit Further

results.snippet: Television entertainment these days is going out of town, quite literally. Urban America on prime time's plethora of law-enforcement shows is infested with crime and social problems. Suburbia isn't much better. Television does, in its way, reflect...
results.lead_paragraph: Television entertainment these days is going out of town, quite literally. Urban America on prime time's plethora of law-enforcement shows is infested with crime and social problems. Suburbia isn't much better. Television does, in its way, reflect reality. Now, more and more, weekly series are fleeing to out-of-the-way towns and villages. The farther away from a big city, it seems, the better. NBC 's "Down Home" (Saturdays at 8:30 P.M.), for instance, takes place down South in a Gulf Coast hamlet. And CBS 's "Evening Shade" (Mondays at 8) gets its title from the name of the real Midwestern town that is its setting. And then, also on CBS (Mondays at 10), there is "Northern Exposure," taking us all the way to Cicely, Alaska, population somewhere between 500 and 850, depending on which census you want to believe.

headline.main: Pulses of Light Give Astronauts New Rhythms

results.snippet: FOR two weeks before their scheduled launching last May, four crew members of the space shuttle Columbia used brute force to readjust their biological clocks so they could work the night shift. They willed themselves to stay up through the night,...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR two weeks before their scheduled launching last May, four crew members of the space shuttle Columbia used brute force to readjust their biological clocks so they could work the night shift. They willed themselves to stay up through the night, watching old movies to stave off slumber. By day, they took to their beds, tossing and turning, determined to sleep. They ate dinner at dawn and breakfast at night. Although they had the right stuff, they felt awful.

headline.main: Shuttle's Crew Members: 5 Are on First Space Trip

results.snippet: Michael L. Coats Mission Commander    Captain Coats, 45 years old, is a graduate of the United States Naval Academy who grew up in Riverside, Calif. He became an astronaut in 1979, and this is his third space flight.
results.lead_paragraph: Michael L. Coats Mission Commander Captain Coats, 45 years old, is a graduate of the United States Naval Academy who grew up in Riverside, Calif. He became an astronaut in 1979, and this is his third space flight.
